online.common
Class SimpleSprite

java.lang.Object
  online.common.SimpleSprite
All Implemented Interfaces:
SpriteProtocol
public class SimpleSprite
extends java.lang.Object
implements SpriteProtocol

this is a mostly simple implementation of SpriteProtocol, which should be adequate for any simple requirement to drag a sprite across the screen.

Author:
ddyer

                    double duration,
                    int from_x,
                    int from_y,
                    int to_x,
                    int to_y)
constructor

Parameters:
ch - a stockart chip to be drawn
width - the chip's display size
start - the number of seconds to delay before starting
duration - the number of seconds to the end of the animation
from_x - staring x coordinate
from_y - starting y coordinate
to_x - ending x coordinate
to_y - ending y coordinate

public boolean isAlwaysActive()
Description copied from interface: SpriteProtocol
Used when chaining several steps to the endpoint, where the endpoint is already placed.

Specified by:
isAlwaysActive in interface SpriteProtocol
Returns:
true if this animation is always active.

setFromEqualTo

public void setFromEqualTo()

isOverlapped

public boolean isOverlapped()
if true, this animation deliberately overlaps the contents of the destination cell. If false, the content of the animation cell are suppressed until the animation finishes

Specified by:
isOverlapped in interface SpriteProtocol
Returns:
true if the destination should remain visible rather than being invisible until the animation finishes

setRandomWander

public void setRandomWander()
set the sprite to wander slightly. A secondary point inside the start-finish rectangle is chosen at random. This point interpolates toward the endpoint and the starting point interpolates toward the random point instead of the eventual endpoint.

animationHeight

public int animationHeight()
return the height of this animation element. This is used to reduce the height of the destination stack when animating a move. In most cases this will be "1", but when moving a stack as a single element, it's the height of the stack.

Specified by:
animationHeight in interface SpriteProtocol
